summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2021, primarily featuring Richard C. Curtiss attempting to contact various news organizations and government officials regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein, alleged court corruption, and his personal legal grievances. It includes internal forwarding notes and reveals Curtiss's claim of having been inside the MCC SHU where Epstein died and his attempts to get the story covered.

persons.name: Richard C. Curtiss
persons.context: Individual from Wayland, New York, who is contacting news outlets and officials about Jeffrey Epstein's death, alleged government corruption, and his own legal issues. He claims to have been inside the SHU at MCC where Epstein died.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Convicted sex offender whose death by hanging in the Metropolitan Correctional Center is the central subject of the correspondence, with questions raised about the circumstances.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as potentially holding a 'final stash' of blackmail material related to Epstein and as a figure involved in plea negotiations.

persons.name: Jim W. Dean
persons.context: News editor contacted by Richard Curtiss who initially declines the story as 'too narrow' and 'local', but later provides commentary on Epstein.

persons.name: Randolph T.
persons.role: Customer Care Advocate, The New York Times
persons.context: New York Times customer service representative responding to Richard Curtiss's contact.

persons.name: David Schoen
persons.context: Attorney who reportedly met with Epstein in jail on the day of his death to discuss taking over his defense; he is cited as doubting the suicide ruling.

persons.name: Barbara Sampson
persons.context: Official who ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging. Curtiss emails her office asking for drug test results.

persons.name: Robert Katzmann
persons.role: Chief Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
persons.context: Recipient of emails from Curtiss; an auto-reply indicates he was out of the office in February 2016.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: One of the government officials (along with Pelosi and Nadler) to whom Curtiss sent complaints about government employee unions and his alleged false arrests.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: One of the government officials to whom Curtiss sent complaints.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: One of the government officials to whom Curtiss sent complaints.

persons.name: Chuck Schumer
persons.context: Copied on Curtiss's email to House officials.

persons.name: Keith Castaldo
persons.context: Copied on Curtiss's email to House officials.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Mentioned in a news excerpt about his firing not being related to the Russia investigation.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Mentioned in a news excerpt commenting on Comey's firing.

persons.name: Alexander Vindman
persons.context: Mentioned in a fragment of text as the 'original source' of a Ukraine investigation.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as potentially holding blackmail material related to Epstein and involved in plea negotiations following his death.
Schoen met with Epstein in jail to discuss taking over his defense on the day Epstein died.
Curtiss repeatedly contacted Dean, a news editor, pitching stories about Epstein and court corruption.
Curtiss emailed the Chief Medical Examiner's office requesting drug test results from Epstein's autopsy.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by hanging (ruled a suicide) in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City.

events.title: OCME Confirms Suicide Ruling
events.description: The NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, via Dr. Barbara Sampson, publicly confirmed the suicide ruling for Epstein's death.

events.title: Curtiss Pitches Epstein Story to Reuters
events.description: Richard Curtiss emails editor Jim Dean, offering information about being inside the MCC SHU where Epstein died and questioning guard procedures.

events.title: New York Times Customer Care Response
events.description: The New York Times Customer Care responds to Richard Curtiss, directing him to other teams for news assistance.

events.title: Internal Email on Handling Curtiss Inquiry
events.description: An internal email discusses how to handle Richard Curtiss's inquiry, suggesting forwarding it to 'PC chiefs' or civilian complaints.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York City, NY (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, 520 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10016
Federal Bureau of Prisons, 320 First Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20534
keyFacts: Richard C. Curtiss claims to have been inside the Special Housing Unit (SHU) of the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died and questions why guards turned cameras off and failed to perform 30-minute checks.
An email from Jim W. Dean suggests Epstein was a 'huge blackmail jackpot' and that Ghislaine Maxwell may hold a 'final stash' of toxic information that prosecutors would avoid.
Attorney David Schoen is cited as doubting Epstein's suicide, based on meeting him earlier the same day to discuss taking over his defense.

The document shows a pattern of Richard Curtiss contacting numerous news organizations and government officials with allegations of widespread court corruption and his personal legal grievances, largely being dismissed or redirected.
The NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner confirmed Epstein's death as a suicide by hanging but declined to specify if drug tests were performed.
